Barsilisa is a young, widowed woman. She lives alone in the Remancito neighborhood. She has no children.  

She has a small business selling clothes in her home.  She also works mornings at the judicial branch in order to increase her income.  She buys the clothes from Argentina and Brazil, traveling weekly to those destinations. 

She started with money she saved from previous jobs, growing her business month to month  with the salary she receives from her other business. 
      
She is a very responsible person who wants to get ahead. She has a jovial and enterprising spirit and there is no doubt that she will reach  
all of the goals she has set for herself.

loans.use: To buy t-shirts, flip-flops, shorts, dresses and more.

loans.name: Julia Geoconda

texts.es:
Julia Geoconda C. M. tiene 58 años. Es viuda, vive con los nietos, vive en el cantón de Chillanes en la Provincia de Bolívar. Tiene 3 hijos, todos mayores de edad.

Los miembros de la V.R.C. LA ESPERANZA NUNCA SE PIERDE, pertenece a la comunidad o recinto el Placer, a una distancia de 120 minutos de la oficina en Chillanes, los miembros de esta ventanilla en su mayoría se dedican a la agricultura.

Julia se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz, cacao y crianza de pollos. Las compras y ventas las realiza en el Cantón Chillanes en la feria de los días Domingos.

Solicita el crédito para la comprar de semillas, abonos y fertilizantes para que la producción sea de calidad. Con el apoyo del crédito le ayudaría económicamente para suplir sus necesidades. Enfrentan desafíos como las plagas y enfermedades y la variedad del clima. Su sueño es tener terrenos propios para trabajar y no vivir arrendado.

Le gusta coser, cuidar con los animales, jugar con los nietos y la navidad festejar con la comunidad.
texts.en:
J58-year old Julia Geoconda C. M. is a widow and lives with her grandchildren in Chillanes canton, in Bolivar province. She has three adult children.

The members of V.R.C. La Esperanza Nunca se Pierde (Hope never Dies) Community Bank live in the community of El Placer, about 120 minutes from the office in Chillanes. The majority of the group work in agriculture.

Julia is one of them. She grows corn and cocoa, and raises chickens. Her purchases and sales are made in Chillanes canton, at the Sunday market. She is seeking a loan to buy seeds, manure, and fertilizer so that her crops are of good quality. The loan will help her provide for her needs. Julia faces problems such as pests, plant disease, and weather. Her dream is to have land of her own to farm and not have to rent it. She enjoys sewing, looking after the animals, playing with her grandchildren, and joining in the community Christmas festivities.

loans.use: to buy seeds, manure, and fertilizer

loans.name: Juana Cristina

texts.es:
Juana Cristina es una joven de 19 años de edad , termino el tercer año de seundaria y decidio no estudiar mas, esto para dedicarse de tiempo completo en la actividad de venta de calzados por catalogo y en un pequeño establecimiento, este negocio ha significado mucho para Juana. Actualmente esta soltera y no tiene planes de tener una relacion sentimental con alguien, ella vive con su mama que desde ya hace algunos años se separo de sus esposo, haciendo del negocio una de sus mas grandes prioridades para seguir adelante.
Juana solicito un credito para invertirlo en la compra de mas calzado, con este dinero pudo comprar tenis deportivos, sandalias, zapato para caballero de vestir y escolares, zapatillas, huaraches y algunos calzados para niños y bebes.
Con esto espera tener mas ventas y ofrecerles mas productos a sus clientes, obteniendo mas ganacias para invertir, para el pago de su credito y para el crecimiento del mismo. Una de sus esperanzas es tener su propio local independiente, mas espacio, mas mercancia, le gustaria tenr su propia casa y apoyar mas a sus hermano en su preparacion escolar.Su esperanza es que sus metas se cumplan y que algun dia pueda mejorara mas sus calidad de vida, para no repetir la misma historia de su madre.
Juan le esta muy agradecida a fundacion realidad y a los que apoyan a kiva por ayudar a realiazar el sueño de muchos en todas partes del mundo, para todos ellos les manda un  abrazo.
texts.en:
Juana Cristina is a young woman of 19 years of age. She finished the 3rd grade of secondary school and decided not to study any more so that she could dedicate herself full-time to her work selling shoes from a catalog and in a small store. This business has meant a lot to Juana. She is currently single and has no plans to have a relationship with anyone. She lives with her mother who has been separated from her husband for some years. The business is one of her greatest priorities in moving forward in her life. 
Juana is requesting a loan to buy more shoes. With this money, she could buy tennis shoes, sandals, men's dress shoes and school shoes, slippers, loafers, and some shoes for children and babies. 
She hopes that this will result in increased sales as she will be able to offer more products to her customers and this will give her more profits to invest to repay her loan and to grow her business. One of her hopes is that she will have her own independent business, more space, and more merchandise. She would like to have her own house and help her brother more in his studies. She hopes to reach her goals and that some day she can improve her quality of life so that she does not repeat the same mistakes as her mother. 
Juana is very grateful to Fundacion Realidad and to those who are supporting her through Kiva and helping people around the world to realize their dreams. She sends a hug to all of them.

loans.use: To buy shoes for sale: shoes, tennis shoes, sandals, loafers, slippers, and shoes for children and babies.

loans.name: Juana Terresa

texts.es: Juana tiene 46 años de edad, es casada , originaria del Departamento de Totonicapán, cuenta con tres hijos dos varones y una mujer, asi como también con su esposo cruz , juntos han logrado salir adelante ya que se dedican al comercio y cuentan con 15 años de experiencia , ella esta solicitando el cuarto crédito en asociación ASDIR ya que cuenta con un record crediticio bueno  estando al día en sus créditos  anteriores.
texts.en: Juana is 46 years old, married, and she is originally from the department of Totonicapan. She has three children, two boys and a girl. She and her husband Cruz have managed to succeed with their work as merchants.  They have 15 years' experience in the field. She requests her fourth loan with Asociacion ASDIR (Kiva Field Partner). She has a good credit rating and she has successfully repaid her previous loans.

loans.use: To purchase products for resale.

loans.name: Rosa Elena

texts.es:
Rosa tiene 56 años. Ella es divorciada y reside junto a sus hijos en el distrito de Olmos, una zona agrícola de bastante movimiento comercial que se encuentra situada en la provincia de Lambayeque, a más de una hora y media de la ciudad de Chiclayo. 

Rosa es muy trabajadora lo que es evidente porque ha trabajado desde que era una niña. Desde hace ocho años ella vende por catálogo productos de belleza por ejemplo colonias, perfumes, y maquillajes.  Ella visita a sus vecinos y amistades y les ofrece sus productos.  Cuando empezó su negocio, Rosa sólo contaba con muestras y tenía poco productos. En los últimos 10 meses, Rosa ha podido crecer su negocio un poco más porque ahora tiene una vitrina para mostrar sus productos. 

Rosa desea invertir su crédito en su negocio para adquirir más productos y poder incrementar su capital de trabajo. Para lograr su objetivo ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles. Rosa se siente muy contenta por la confianza que los prestatarios de Kiva y Edpyme Alternativa deposita en ella y por la ayuda que le brinda a mejorar su vida poco a poco.
texts.en:
Rosa is 56 years old.  She is divorced and lives with her children in Olmos district: an agricultural area with quite a lot of commercial activity which is located in Lambayeque province, more than one and a half hours from the city of Chiclayo.

Rosa is a very hard-working woman who has worked since she was a little girl.  For the past eight years she has been selling beauty products such as cologne, perfume and make-up through a catalog.  She visits her neighbors and friends and offers them her products for sale.  When she started her business, Rosa only had samples and few products.  Over the last 10 months, Rosa has been able to grow her business a little more because now she has a display cabinet for displaying her products.

Rosa would like to invest her loan in her business so that she can acquire more products and increase her working capital.  In order to achieve her goal she is requesting a loan for 1,000 Peruvian soles from Edpyme Alternativa.  Rosa feels very happy for the trust that Kiva lenders and Edpyme Alternativa are placing in her and for the help that they are providing her with so that she can gradually improve her life.

loans.use: To acquire more products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more kitchen utensils for resale.

loans.name: Suzanne

texts.en:
Suzanne was born in 1957 and is married with five children. She and her husband Etienne still have two children to look after, who both attend school. They live in Porto-Novo, Benin's administrative capital.

Suzanne sells beans and bread at her stall, which has been her activity for the last 20 years. This is her fifth loan with ALIDE, following successful repayments in the past. With this loan she hopes to purchase more stock for her stall. In the long term she hopes to be able to strengthen and enlarge her business.

loans.use: Purchasing additional stock for making food to sell

loans.name: Chella

texts.en:
Chella J. is from the village of Samay, Gingoog City. She is 23 years old and married, with 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Chella runs a sari-sari (variety)  store, where she sells canned goods, snack foods, shampoo, soap and beverages. Chella has been engaged in her business for more than 3 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Chella joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Chella has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Chella is requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods and beverages. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Chella from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods and beverages

loans.name: Araceli

texts.es: Araceli tiene 38 años de edad, es casada y tiene un hijo de dos años de edad. Vive junto a su familia en casa propia ubicado en el distrito de Eten en el norte de Perú. Araceli se dedica a la confección y venta de artesanía. Elabora sombreros de junco los cuales vende a pedido a sus vecinos y amistades en su caserío y zonas aledañas. También ofrece sus artesanías en ferias y otros eventos locales. Araceli es muy conocida en la zona y cuenta con clienta ya establecida. Además, cuenta con una mototaxi propia que alquila a otros conductores para que brinden servicios de transporte de pasajeros. Con estas actividades, Araceli puede apoyar a su esposo, quien labora como tripulante de pesca industrial, con el sostenimiento económico de su familia. Desea invertir su crédito en la compra de más material de junco para confeccionar sus sombreros. Con esta inversión, Araceli podrá incrementar su producción y mejorar sus ventas.
texts.en: Araceli is 38 years old, married, and has a child who is 2 years old.  She lives with her family in their own home located in the district of Eten in the northern part of Peru.  Araceli makes and sells crafts.  She makes hats made of reed and sells them to friends and neighbors in her neighborhood and surrounding areas.  Araceli is well known in the area and relies on an established clientele.  She also counts on a motortaxi that she rents out to other drivers for them to offer transportation services for passengers.  With these activities she can help her husband who works on an industrial fishing crew, sustain the family's finances.  She wishes to invest her loan in the purchase of more reed material in order to make her hats.  With such an investment, Araceli can increase her production and improve sales.

loans.use: to purchase reed for the making of her hats.

loans.name: Atina

texts.en: Atina is 34 years old and lives with her husband and three sons in a ger, a traditional Mongolian tent, in Bayan-Ulgii province. Her oldest son, age 10, attends a local secondary school while her younger two sons, who are 4 and 5, go to a kindergarten. Her husband is an electrical worker who helps ensure the safety of plants operated by the Power Network Division. Atina makes a living managing a grocery in her town. She started her business two years ago and is now very experienced in selling food from assorted places and cultures, especially a wide range of  fruits and vegetables. She is very good at attracting customers and attributes her business success to good decision-making skills. She says, "I want to expand my business and would also truly love to improve living conditions of my family." She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to buy candies, biscuits and juice to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To buy candies, biscuits and juice to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Aurelia

texts.en:
Aurelia D. is from the village of Kuguita, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 36 years old, married, and has two adult children. To make a living, Aurelia owns and operates a business making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling snacks and other delicacies such as rice and cheese cakes in the local community. Aurelia has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Aurelia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aurelia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional inventory and acquire working capital. Aurelia is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients such as flour, sugar, and milk. This loan will be Aurelia second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients such as flour, sugar, and milk

loans.name: Jose

texts.en:
Jose is a 64-year-old farmer working in the town of Banga, South Cotabato. He tills his own land and prepares it well for crops. Jose grows rice and corn crops on his land. He works hard to provide for his family's needs.

This loan will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. Jose hopes this loan will help improve his harvest.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is 46 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with eight children. 

Regina has a food shop that sells bread, rice & cheese cakes, and beverages. She also serves coffee. She has had this business for four years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy additional breads, beverages & coffee powder.

Regina has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Regina hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy additional breads, beverages & coffee powder

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase wood and other tools for his work

loans.name: Tom

texts.en:
Tom is an industrious 49 year old business man. He is married and blessed with three children aged 11, 6 and 2. He has been operating a retail shop for the last 5 years. He is very grateful to Faulu Kenya because he has learned how to relate with his customers. This has helped him to attract customers and grow his business. In the next five years, he dreams of owning rental apartments.

He wants 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy sugar and rice for sale in his retail shop.

loans.use: To buy sugar and rice for sale

loans.name: Mariana Gillermina

texts.es:
En Los Bajos de Montecristi, ciudad conocida por su gran diversidad de productos típicos, como por ejemplo los sombreros de paja toquillas conocidos dentro y fuera del país se reúnen cada 15  días las socias del Banco Comunal La Dolorosa Del Pechiche.

En este lugar  conocimos a la señora Mariana tiene 45 años  de edad, es madre soltera de un hijo el mismo que ya es mayor de edad pero aun vive con ella, el estudia en la universidad en Manta.  Lleva 3 años en el Banco Comunal y le gusta por la seriedad con la que trabajan en la institución.

Ella trabaja en una casa realizando quehaceres domésticos, pero también en sus ratos libres se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo, su forma de  venta es puerta a puerta, nos cuenta que  además sus clientes le  realizan pedidos. Trabaja todos los días desde las  6h00 hasta las 15h00 realizando sus labores dentro de la casa en la que trabaja pero en las noches ella visita a sus conocidos para ofrecer su mercadería las mismas que  deja a crédito a sus clientes  y cobra en dos o tres pagos. Su mercadería  la va a comprar una vez al mes a  Guayaquil. Nos cuenta que lleva 7 años que se dedica a esta actividad y le va muy bien.

Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar más mercadería como: pantalones, blusas, camisetas y ropa de niños, entre otras prendas.
 
Su sueño es algún dia tener un local bien surtido de mercadería.
texts.en:
The  members of the communal bank, La Dolorosa del Pechiche,  meet every two weeks in the city of Los Bajos de Montecristi, known domestically and internationally for its great variety of typical crafts, such as Panama hats.

Here we meet Mariana, 45, single mother of a son who, although no longer a child, still lives with her.  He is studying at the university in Manta.  She has been with the communal bank for three years and she likes the serious way the institution functions.

She works at home doing housework, but also in her spare time she sells all kinds of clothing door to door.  She tells us that her customers also give her orders.  She does housework daily from 6 am until 3 pm but she visits her acquaintances in the evenings offering them merchandise on credit.    They make two or three payments to purchase the items.  She goes once a month to Guayaquil to buy merchandise and she tells us that she has been selling this way for the past 7 years and it’s going very well.

Mariana will use the loan to buy more merchandise such as: pants, blouses, shirts, children’s clothing, and other items.

Her dream is to have a stand in the future supplied with merchandise

loans.use: To buy pants, blouses, shirts, and children's clothing

loans.name: Sauda

texts.en:
Sauda is 42 years old and is married with seven children. Additionally, she takes care of three relatives. Sauda sells food and drinks in her restaurant such as tea, bread, and so on. Her business is well-organized and she has one year of experience. Sauda works from five in the morning through nine at night and currently employs one person to help her.

Sauda is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via the Vision Finance Company to purchase more food and drink to sell in her restaurant. With her profits, Sauda will reinvest in her business and save for her future.

loans.use: to purchase food and drink to sell in her restaurant

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita is 37 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. 

Juanita has a shop that sells snacks, beverages & canned goods. She has had this business for six years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, beverages & snacks.

Juanita has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Juanita hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, beverages & snacks.

loans.name: José

texts.es:
José en Soledad, municipio a 15 minutos D. la ciudad D. Barranquilla, tiene una fábrica D. bollos, la que inició al llegar a la Costa Caribe, desplazado D. su tierra y con la necesidad D. generar ingresos para su familia conformada por su esposa y sus hijos, hoy en las edades D. 20 a 26 años.  Su hermano fue fundamental en este momento porque lo ayudó con un pequeño capital con el que inició fabricando productos en cantidades pequeñas, logrando gradualmente aumentar su producción pues la pureza D. sus productos lo ayudaron a incrementar su clientela, aunque debió para ello asumir el desafío D. hacer préstamos a tasas onerosas, lo cual ha logrado superar. En su crecimiento D. negocio ha logrado comprar un motor y adaptarlo a su molino para hacer eficiente la producción. Su sueño más adelante es tener una casa propia y un local acondicionado para lograr independizarlo del hogar y genera mayor sosiego. Mientras todo esto ocurre, José sigue esforzándose y generando un margen D. utilidad no menor del 45% que le ha permitido continuar y crecer para continuar avanzando con su familia.
Con su credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, comprara materias primas al por mayor, como maíz verD., maíz blanco y azúcar, para producir en mayor escala y aumentar sus ingresos y con ello su capital D. trabajo
texts.en:
José lives in Soledad, a municipality located 15 minutes from Barranquilla. He has a bollo bakery [bollo is a spongy bread roll] that he started up upon moving to the Costa Caribe, displaced from his land and needing to generate an income for his family. His family consists of his wife and their children, who are currently between the ages of 20 and 26. His brother was essential to the business' development because he helped Jose out with a small amount of capital. Jose began making small quantities of products, and was able to gradually increase his production. The purity of his products helped him to gain a customer base. Even though he had to take out loans at burdensome interest rates to do so, he was able to succeed. He has been able to buy a motor and adapt it to his mill to make his production more efficient. His dream for the future is to have his own home and an equipped shop in order to get his business out of his home and have more peace and quiet. Jose is continuing to work hard and generate a margin of utility no lower than 45%, which has allowed him to continue and to expand in order to continue advancing his family.
With his Kiva loan, his first loan from the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, he will purchase basic materials wholesale, such as green corn, white corn, and sugar, in order to produce on a larger scale and increase his income and working capital.

loans.use: to purchase basic materials, such as green corn, white corn and sugar, wholesale.

loans.name: Phuong

texts.en:
Phuong was born in 1971. She lives in Xom Huong village. She is married with three children. Her main job is farming. She not only grows rice but also she and her husband make cakes from rice. (The Vietnamese call it Banh Da.) They have had this job for many years. 

Phuong has a monthly income of about 3,000,000 Vietnamdong (VND). The last time she borrowed 8,066,000 VND and repaid this loan punctually. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 9,374,000 VND to buy rice to make pancakes.

loans.use: to buy rice to make pancakes.

loans.name: Subira Group

texts.en:
Kisinguru, who is in his late 30s, is married with three children who go to school. He has been running a grocery business for 4 years now.  He works from 8 a.m to 8 p.m daily and is able to a fair monthly profit.

This will be his 6th Motisha loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  A Motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania,  given in the middle of the main loan that motivates borrowers with good credit ratings who pay back their  loans  smoothly to receive half the amount of the existing loan before their original loan term has ended. He used his previous loans to increase the range of items from the grocery, for household expenses and also started building his house. He has paid back his loans successfully. He hopes to increase the grocery store inventory.  His dream is to one day be able to finish his house.

He will share this loan with his loan group "Subira" which has a total of 9 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

loans.use: To increase his grocery store inventory.

loans.name: Ros

texts.en:
Ros, 36 years old, sells clothes and drums and earns $10 per day. Her husband is a policeman and earns $3 per day. They have two children, 5 and 3 years old and one is studying. Every month, she has to spend $45 on food, $15 on school fees, and $10 on other expenses. 

She would like to request a loan of $1000 to buy clothes and drums to sell. She has plans to buy other souvenir products to sell in her store so that she can make more money. For her children, she hopes to send them to study in the university.

loans.use: To buy clothes and drums to sell

loans.name: Tomasa

texts.en:
Tomasa is 27 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children.

Tomasa has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks, and beverages. She has had this business for three years. She requested a loan of 15,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages to sell.

Tomasa has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Tomasa hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages to sell.

loans.name: Anapogi

texts.en:
Anapogi is 32 years of age and married. She has three children. 

Anapogi works in her business, catching and selling ocean-caught fish. She has two years of experience in this business. 

Anapogi needs a loan of WST 1,500 to purchase an extra fishing net and fishing equipment. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 250 talas or US $104 per week) to improve and expand the business.

In 2010, Anapogi joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral.  This is Anapogi's second loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase an extra fishing net and fishing equipment.

loans.name: Chizi

texts.en:
Chizi is a married woman with three children, two of whom attend school while one is still too young for school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are for food, school fees and rent bills.

With the Kshs 20,000 she is requesting, she wants to start a food vending business and purchase sacks of beans, wheat flour, potatoes and cooking fat and oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of beans, wheat flour, potatoes and cooking fat and oil.

loans.name: Saida Mwinyi

texts.en: Saida is a 36 year old married woman. She describes herself as trustworthy. She operates a retail shop where she sells household goods like drinks, maize flour, detergents, etc. She has been involved in this business for 1 year. Her business is located in Mishomoroni, a suburb of Mombasa, and her primary customers are students, teachers and new customers. She says her biggest business challenges are inadequate capital and the increasing price of goods. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to add to her stock of household goods. Her business goal is to run more retail stores within 5 years.

loans.use: to add to her stock of household goods

loans.name: Amnie Anabel

texts.es:
La socia Amnie pertenece al banco comunal "LAS LEONAS DE SAN JERONIMO", el banco se encuentra ubicado en el distrito se San Jeronimo en la provincia y departamento de Cusco.

La socia tiene 37 años de edad; la socia es soltera; La socia es Obstetra de profesión, La socia trabaja  independientemente en su propio centro obstetra; la socia tambien trabaja particularmente, ella en la actualidad desea poder implementar us centro de salud y para ello desea invertir el prestamo enla comra de medicamentos basicos para las diferentes atenciones, ella desea crecer poco a poco y para ello esta poniendo sus primeras bases. La socia solicita el prestamo para invertir en la compra de medicamentos para implementar su centro obstetra.


 
La socia está contenta con el crédito otorgado y agradece a los inversionistas de kiva.
texts.en:
Amnie belongs to the communal bank Las Leonas de San Jeronimo. The communal bank is located in the district of San Jeronimo in the province and department of Cusco.

She is 37 years old, and single. She is an obstetrician. She works independently, in her own obstetric center. 

She also works conscientiously, and currently she wants to be able to expand her health center and to do this she needs to invest the loan to buy basic medicine for different applications. She wants to grow little by little and she is building from the ground up. 

She is asking for this loan in order to buy medicine to use in her obstetric office.

She is happy with the given loan and she thanks the Kiva loaners.

loans.use: to buy medicine to use in her obstetric office

loans.name: Jasho Group

texts.en:
Isaack is the facilitator of the Jasho group, Isaack and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Isaack takes care of nine children at home. He joined One Acre Fund to access One Acre Fund’s best prices and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Isaack had an excellent maize yield harvesting nine bags on ½ acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Isaack was only able to harvest 3½ bags of maize on ½ acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Isaack and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, Isaack will educate his children, build a house and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Jasho group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Isaack is pictured with his group members and the field officer who is standing on the far left.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet is a 39-year-old businesswoman who lives in Juba. She is married and has 3 children between the ages of 4 and 14, all of whom go to school. 

Annet runs a food store, and she has been in the business for 7 years. She has one employee. Annet heard about Finance Sudan through her fellow clients and outreach and promotion done by the loan officers. She is requesting a loan of SDG 2500 to purchase more food items, such as sacks of maize and many others. Aside from this business, Annet has no other source of income.

In 5 years' time, Annet hopes to see her store expand. Her major challenges include school fees, home expenses, and the high cost of living in Juba. 

Annet says that she is happy for Finance Sudan’s support, especially for women.

loans.use: to purchase more food items, such as sacks of maize

loans.name: Alaaeddeen

texts.en:
AlaaEddeen is a 28-year-old young man who is the father of one son. He is a Palestinian National Authority employee with a decent salary. To increase his income, AlaaEddeen also has a store for selling broilers to customers.

AlaaEddeen wants to purchase broilers in bulk for resale, but the amount of money he has isn't enough to pay, so he needs to take a loan from FATEN. When AlaaEddeen gets the loan, he will purchase more broilers. This will enable him to compete with others in the same field and to increase his sales and income, thereby creating better living conditions for the family.

AlaaEddeen is photographed in the picture.

loans.use: To purchase broilers in bulk for resale

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is a forty-five-year-old married man with four children living in Kyenjojo, Uganda. His family goal is to educate his children to attain high qualifications. He is a farmer who has specialized in commercial maize growing. He acquired money to buy land from the salary he used to earn as an employee of a tea factory. He has challenges of the seasonal nature of the crop and his dream is to diversify and grow groundnuts and coffee.

Francis needs the loan facility to pay workers to harvest his maize.

loans.use: to pay workers to harvest his maize.

loans.name: Mario

texts.en:
My name is Mario, I sell candies and chocolates inside different flee market in Mexico City. My father had the same business and I used to work with him.

I got married 10 years ago, and decided to become independent, that is when I started my own shop. I sell my candies in different flee markets. Monday I am in San Pablo Tlanepantla, Tuesday I move to a market in Nicolas Romero, Wednesday in Atizapan and a different market every day.

Thanks to the business, my family is doing much better. My next goal is to build a house.

loans.use: To buy merchandise. I sell candies and chocolates inside flee markets.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To add stock.

loans.name: Agna Azucena

texts.en:
I have several years experience selling sausages and I have my business run from my own home because I live on the main street of my neighborhood and everyone comes to my home to buy sausages. My suppliers know me because I return to them every week to make my purchases. My business has grown and now I find myself losing business because I need more capital to buy more product.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Tengo varios años de dedicarme a la venta de embutidos, mi negocio lo tengo en mi casa ya que vivo en la calle principal de mi colonia y todas las personas pasan por aca comprando sus embutidos. Mis proveedores ya me conocen por lo que semanal les hago compras. Mi negocio ha crecido y ahora me quedo corta en ventas por lo que necesito capital para comprar mas producto.

loans.use: To purchase ham, various sausages,bologna, cheese and other items.

loans.name: Victor Manuel

texts.en:
Mr. Víctor has had his business for a year. He says "I sell Chicharrones (pork rind) and cueritos at home and I deliver them to several shopping areas. This is what supports me and my family. I would like to buy more raw material to expand my delivery routes and thus obtaining more income. I need to borrow $1,000 to invest in this business."

Translated from Spanish by Isabel Tan, a Kiva volunteer.

El Sr. Víctor tiene 1 año con su negocio “Tengo una venta de Chicharrones y cueritos en mi casa los cuales reparto en varios centros comerciales, de ahí vivimos mi familia y yo, me gustaría poder comprar más materia prima para ampliar mis rutas de entrega y así tener más ingresos". Solicito $ 1,000.00 dlls para invertir en el negocio.

loans.use: Invertor en el negocio

loans.name: Nou

texts.en: Mrs Nou S. is 36 and lives in Siem Reap in Cambodia. She works at a hotel. Her husband is a construction foreman. They have 3 children and between them earn 6 dollars a day.  The loan would allow them to repair their house and be protected from leaks during the rainy season.

loans.use: To repair her house

loans.name: Maria Victoria

texts.es:
Maria is a hardworking woman with three children currently in school. Unfortunately, four years ago Maria’s husband suffered an automobile accident and lost his life, leaving the family without any kind of help. Maria has had to make great efforts to move forward with her life and her family, so she started her own business selling soft drinks and snacks. She maD. a lot of headway and today, with the help of her children, she has her own corner market.

This market has been the only source of income for her home. Maria now seeks $475 dollars of credit which she promises to payback in 6 months. With this money Maria will be able to improve the variety of products in her store and continue the growth of her business. Today you can help someone who really needs it; this family deeply thanks you for your trust and support.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Pendleton, Kiva volunteer.

Maria es una mujer muy trabajadora, tiene tres hijos que están estudiando. Lamentablemente hace cuatro años su esposo sufrió un accidente automovilístico y perdió la vida, dejando a su familia sin ningún tipo D. ayuda, para sacar adelante a su familia Maria ha tenido que esforzase mucho e inició su propio negocio con la venta D. refrescos y botanas, que después comenzó a surtir mejor hasta tener ahora su tienda D. abarrotes, donD. recibe la ayuda D. sus hijos y juntos han logrado hacer crecer este negocio.

Esta tienda ha sido la única fuente D. ingresos para este hogar y para darle un nuevo impulso ahora Maria esta solicitando un crédito D. $ 475 dólares que se compromete a devolver en 6 meses, con esto ella podrá mejorar la variedad D. productos que comercializa y continuará creciendo con su negocio. Hoy puedes ayudar a quien más lo necesita, esta familia agradece mucho la confianza y apoyo que les brindas.

loans.use: Purchase of Merchadise

loans.name: Soila Martha

texts.en:
Soila Martha V. E. belongs to a village bank called “Llamkasun,” which is a Quechua (native language) word that means “We Work Together.”

A proud mother of three children who currently attend the local university, Soila is the owner of a restaurant called “La Perla,” or The Pearl. She serves traditional Peruvian dishes such as “Pachamanca,” a dish dating back to the Incas, which consists of different types of seasoned meats and is cooked over hot stones. Soila does all the cooking herself, seven days a week, because she says it’s the only way she can assure the quality of the food she serves. The restaurant also provides a small pool and playground for the children, who come to eat with their families, making it a very popular destination on the weekends when the restaurant is filled with families spending the day together.

Soila got her start in the restaurant business by preparing “ceviche,” another popular Peruvian dish made from fresh fish and lime, and selling it door to door in the small town where she lives. Through very hard work, Soila was able to save up enough money to rent and eventually buy the building, which now houses her very own restaurant.

Soila says she is very happy to be a part of her village bank and that she would not have been able to afford the opportunities she has been given without its help. Soila is asking for a $700 loan, with which she will be able to buy food supplies for her restaurant and maintain the pool for the children.

loans.use: Soila is asking for a $700 loan, with which she will be able to buy food supplies for her restaurant and maintain the pool for the children.

loans.name: Christian Rural

texts.en:
Alex K. Gurah is a welder at Moree junction near cape coast. He has his own shop. He is also married with four children ages 12, 8, 6 and 2 years respectively. The wife is a trader and she sells foodstuffs. Alex also manufactures baking ovens, coalpot (traditional stove used for cooking here in Ghana). He has lots of customers. In addition to this, Alex also sells car plates. At Alex shop, lots of car has been parked there awaiting body works (maintenance). He also has three apprentices understudying him.
One major challenge that Alex faces is that most of his customers do not make full payment when they bring their cars to him for repairs so he has to look for money to complete their work for them before full payment is made.
Alex is asking for a loan of US $ 1,000 dollars to enable him buy more materials such as car plates for repairing car bodies, manufacture ovens, buy gas, electrodes for welding.

loans.use: Alex is asking for a loan of US $ 1,000 dollars to enable him buy more materials such as car plates for repairing car bodies, manufacture ovens, buy gas, electrodes for welding.

loans.name: Selina

texts.en:
Despite Tanzania's being a "developing" country, it is amazing how many people have mobile phones here -- not just professionals, but grandmothers in villages, school kids and street sellers. These phones are the only form of phone communication available to most people, because there are few landlines, and they are relatively inexpensive to own and use.

Selina N. is one of the many sellers trying to satisfy Tanzania’s insatiable appetite for anything mobile phone-related. She owns a phone from which people can make calls, and sells phone credit and accessories (such as batteries, chargers, earphones and cases). Selina requires a loan of $275 to purchase more of this stock. At just 38 she is already a widow, and the business enables her to support her two children, Issak, 19, and Barnaba, 15.

About SELFINA


SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania, where customs and traditions normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets. Because they lack tangible collateral assets, women are considered not creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low income.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA buys equipment and leases it to women. When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from her, extending her a loan, and then leases the same equipment back to her – a process called "sale and leaseback."

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of phone accessories for sale

loans.name: Sumiati

texts.en: Sumiati, 33, is the mother of 3 children. Her husband, D., has no fixed job so she has to work to earn income for the family by selling foods such doughnuts, cakes, etc., earning $5 a day. She is a member of MBK and is asking for a loan of $75 to expand her business. She will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: expansion of her little food business

loans.name: Dobbi B(I) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Margret N.. She is currently in the business of selling chicken and is requesting a loan to add to her business. Margret is 39 years old and is married. She has 4 children ranging from ages 10 to 20, who go to school. Each week, Margret makes approximately UGX 70000 in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees and build for her grandchildren.

Margret is joined in her small group by Agnes K., Mary N., Norah K., and Annet N.. Agnes K. has a grocery store and wants to increase her inventory. Mary N. sells chickens and wants a loan to purchase more chickens to sell. Norah K. sells fruit and wants to stock more fruits and vegetables. Annet N. sells vegetables and is requesting a loan to boost her business.

loans.use: To improve chicken selling business

loans.name: Vladimir

texts.en:
Vladimir has a business selling auto parts, tools and other small items at an outdoor market in Kahovka, Ukraine. He is an experienced entrepreneur, having been in business for about seven years.

Auto sales are booming in Ukraine. Higher incomes and the availability of credit have made car ownership possible for more and more people. This is a good sign for business owners like Vladimir who benefit from more customers needing parts and equipment for their vehicles.

Vladimir currently has about $2500 invested in inventory and makes about $300 in profit each month. He has requested a loan of $600 to add to his working capital and allow him to purchase new inventory to sell. We are happy to have the opportunity to assist Vladimir with his business and look forward to seeing him continue to be successful.

loans.use: Purchase inventory for his auto parts store.

loans.name: Esthela

texts.es:
Señora C. has a travel services business for trips to different parts of Mexico, like tourist destinations. This is the source of income for her family since her husband and siblings work there as well. They are requesting a loan of $1,200 to remodel their location.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La Sra. C. tiene un negocio de servicios de viajes a diferentes partes de la Republica Mexicana, así como a lugares turísticos. Este es la fuente de ingreso de su familia ya que en trabajan su esposo y sus hermanos. Estamos solicitando un préstamo de $1,200.00 dlls para acondicionar un local ya que tiene en su casa el negocio y están algo reducido.

loans.use: To remodel her location

loans.name: Gladys Esther

texts.es:
Gladys is 40 years old and lives with her partner in the district of Florencia D. Mora, in the Trujillo provence. She completed her primary education, and has 4 children, two of whom are going to school and depend on Gladys.

She has her small business on the corner of the plaza, where she sells local snacks and sweets such as rice with milk or ice creams. Depending on the season, she sells different snacks. She began her business 3 years ago with the first loan. Her cousin recommended that she join the communal bank called Las Conquistadoras II.

With the new loan, which she will repay in 4 months, she will purchase more products for her small stand. She dreams about having a larger business in her own home, so she could be closer to her young sons, for whom she works hard constantly.

Gladis es una señora que tien 40 años D. edad, es conviviente vive en el Distrito D. Florencia D. Mora, Provincia D. Trujillo, Departamento D. La Libertad; estudió la primaria completa; tiene 04 hijos dos D. los cuales aun están estudiando y dependen D. ella. Tiene su negocio en la esquina D. la plaza D. armas del distrito ella venD. mazamorra, arroz con leche, raspadilla, es decir ella venD. por temporadas D. acuerdo a la estación así en verano venD. hielo, raspadilla, etc. Ella se inicio en la venta sólo D. raspadilla hace 03 años más o menos con el primer préstamo otorgado por Manuela Ramos, el cual fue D. S/.200.oo nuevos soles.La señora Ádelina ingresa al Banco Comunal “ Las Conquistadoras II ” por información D. su prima. Con el préstamo D. S/.1,500.00, el cual cancelará en 4 meses, lo utilizara para la compra D. ajo y para surtir el puesto D. fruta. La señora Adelina sueña con un negocio más granD. en su casa , y así estar mas al pendiente D. sus menores hijos por los cuales ella se esfuerza y lucha continuamente.

loans.use: TO PURCHASE MORE PRODUCTS TO SELL FROM HER SMALL SNACK STAND

loans.name: Nguyen Ngoc

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyen Ngoc M., joined the TYM Fund since 2000. At that time, her family’s main activity is to run a small studio on ID and wedding pictures. At first, she borrowed 40 USD to buy a more modern camera. Later, she used the borrowed to send her husband to a photography class. She now expands her studio and they also do typing documents for customers. She has to hire one helper to assist her with the studio’s work with a wage of 80 USD/month. This time, she wants to borrow 1150 USD to upgrade her studio. Her family average income is 625 USD/month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Ngọc M. 38 tuổi, tham gia Quỹ Tình Thương năm 2000, lúc đó gia đình chị làm nghề chụp ảnh thẻ và đám cưới. Khi tham gia Quỹ vòng vốn đầu chị vay 500.000đ để mua một chiếc máy ảnh với nhiều tính năng hơn. Các vòng vốn sau chị đầu tư cho anh đi học nâng cao tay nghề chụp ảnh và quay phim và làm ảnh kỹ thuật số. Cho đến nay gia đình chị đã có 1 cửa hàng khá khang trang với các dich vụ như quay phim, chụp ảnh kỹ thuật số, photo coppy và đánh máy vi tính, với số lượng công việc nhiều gia đình anh chị phải thuê 1 người phụ giúp với mức lương 1.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 19.000.000đ đầu tư vào cửa hàng. Thu nhập bình quân. 10.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: upgrade photography studio

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah B. operates a restaurant. She is a trader as well. She is married, but her husband's income is not sufficient to support Hannah and her child.

Hannah has many customers. She is asking for a loan for more capital so she can expand her restaurant, and so increase her profits.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her restaurant.

loans.name: Sharafniso

texts.en:
Sharafniso S. is 48 year old widow with three children. Sharafniso has almost never had anyone's assistance in helping her children get ahead. For fifteen years she has worked as a baker, making the national Tajik bread, “lepeshka”. Sharafniso works hard to earn an honest livelihood. She gets up early and bakes lepeshka so that people have fresh bread on their tables for breakfast. Initially Sharafniso only baked the bread and was not involved in selling it. Gradually, however, the business expanded as her children grew up. Today the bakery is a family business where Sharafniso’s children help her. Sharafniso sells her bread in the local market place where she has many clients. These sales allow her to improve her family’s income.

Today Sharafniso requests 3400 Somoni (1,000 USD) in order to purchase flour and firewood for baking lepeshka. She assures lenders that she will be ready to repay the loan in twelve months and thanks everyone for trusting and supporting her. The well-being of her family is in your hands.

loans.use: Purchasing of flour and firewood to bake national bread, “lepeshka”

loans.name: Robiyajon

texts.en:
S. Robiyajon is 50 years old. She is married with four children. Robiyajon has always had a trying life. Supporting the large family was very difficult for her husband, that’s why she decided to start her own business. Struggling against the difficult life, Robiyajon learned processing dried fruits and cling-stone apricots six years ago. The business went successfully after it started. Thanks to this activity she could fight to provide for her family and educate her children, who today are working adults thanks to her example.

Today this friendly woman is requesting a loan of US$600 for the term of nine months. She wants to use this loan for purchasing more dried fruits due to great demand from her customers. Robiyajon and her family are sincerely thankful for your support.

loans.use: Purchasing dried fruits for processing and further selling.

loans.name: Benkadi (Unity Is Good) Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi est un regroupement de sept femmes du  deuxième quartier de la ville de Koutiala (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans et  6 enfants. Les femmes du groupe Benkadi vivent dans des familles polygames avec leurs enfants, les coépouses, les beaux parents, les frères et soeurs et d’autres parents.
Ce groupe fait essentiellement le commerce des condiments alimentaires et souvent les pâtes alimentaires, les chaussures et l’habillement.
Se connaissant depuis de longue date et se faisant mutuellement confiance, elles ont décidé ensemble d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis deux ans. Benkadi est à son troisième prêt solidaire(prêt de groupe) après avoir remboursé sans difficulté les deux précédents. Le prêt actuel sera utilusé pour acheter, des cartons de lait, des sacs d’oignons, des cartons de macaroni etc auprès des grossistes en provenance de la république du Ghana, de Dakar (capitale  de la république du Sénégal et d’Abidjan ( capitale de la Côte d’ivoire).
Avec une clientèle à majorité constituée de femmes, les membres de ce groupe effectuent leurs ventes exclusivement au marché de Koutiala très généralement au comptant. Elles comptent réaliser en moyenne 100 000 CFA par cycle et ambitionnent de devenir des grossistes et aller faire des achats dans les pays cités ci dessus..
NB La nommée Mariam Dembélé est absente de la photo de groupe pour des raisons de visites prénatales.
texts.en:
Benkadi is a group of 7 women from the second suburb of the town of Koutiala (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They have an average age of 37 and on average, 6 children. The women of the Benkadi group live in polygamous families with their children, co-spouses, parents-in-law, brothers, sisters, and other relatives.

This group basically sells condiments and often also pasta, shoes, and clothing.

Since they have known each other for a long time and trust one another, they decided to come together to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso two years ago. Benkadi is on its third solidarity loan (group loan) after having reimbursed the two preceding ones without difficulty. This third loan will be used to buy cartons of milk, sacks of onions, cartons of macaroni, etc. from the wholesalers--goods which come from the Republic of Ghana, from Dakar (capital of Senegal) and from Abidjan (capital of the Cote d'Ivoire).

Having a clientele mainly consisting of women, the members of this group make their sales exclusively in the market of Koutiala, generally on a cash basis. They expect to make, on average, 100,000 CFA each time they have sold off what they bought and their ambition is to become wholesalers and go to do their own buying in the aforementioned cities.

Note that Mariam Dembélé is absent from the photo because she had a prenatal checkup at that time.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of condiments for re-sale

loans.name: Berita Marina

texts.es:
La señora Berita pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Divinas ubicado en el Jr. Pucallpa Nº 655, distrito de Callería, provincia de Coronel Portillo, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 35 años de edad, es madre de 2 hijos menores de edad que aún dependen de ella, es casada y su esposo es independiente en su trabajo. Con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decide invertir en la venta de comida. Tiene 2 años trabajando con el banco comunal.

En la actualidad cuenta con el mismo negocio y tiene el apoyo de su esposo. Vende todas las noches en el patio de su vivienda.
  
Con este préstamo de S/. 1,800, el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará 4 kilos de arroz, 2 racimos de plátanos, 3 pollos, 5 kilos de chorizo, etc.

Berita trabaja día a día y con mucho entusiasmo para darles una mejor educación a sus queridos y pequeños hijos.
texts.en:
Ms. Berita D. is a member of the Las Divinas microfinance institute, located on Nº 655 Pucallpa Street, district of Callería, Coronel Portillo province, department of Ucayali. She is 35 years old and has 2 dependent children. She is married, and her husband is self-employed. She decided to invest her first 300.00 PEN loan from Manuela Ramos in food sales. She has been working with the microfinance institute for 2 years.

She currently owns the aforementioned business and has her husband’s support. She sells food every night on her own patio.

With this 1,800.00 PEN loan, which will be repaid in 6 months, she will purchase 4 kg of rice, 2 bunches of plantains, 3 chickens, 5 kg of chorizo, etc.

Berita works everyday with so much enthusiasm in order to provide her beloved young children with a better education.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice, plantains, chicken, chorizo, etc.

loans.name: Lina

texts.es: Lina tiene 57 años, vive con sus 2 hijos. Ella vende animales después de un tiempo de crianza, donde los mantiene con una dieta balanceada para que los animales estén gordos y de esta manera ver las utilidades de su venta, desde hace más de 30 años Lina se viene dedicando a esta actividad que le permite  tener los ingresos necesarios para vivir y apoyar a sus hijos en sus estudio. Ella se siente muy contenta de realizar esta labor, ya que lo disfruta y quiere seguir adelante con ella, además, ordeña cada día a sus vacas para vender 20 litros diarios a las compañías de productos lácteos, así seguirá esforzándose, sobre todo para apoyar a la última de sus hijas que está estudiando. Es la segunda vez que Lina solicita un préstamo con MFP, y ha demostrado puntualidad en sus pagos de devoluciones. Esta cantidad la utilizará en la compra de un becerro, para aumentar el número de su ganado.
texts.en:
Lina is a 57-year-old woman who lives with her 2 children. She sells livestock after raising them for a period of time, when she keeps the animals on a balanced diet so that they can be fat. Thus, she can see profits from selling them. For over 30 years, Lina has been in this business, which has allowed her to have the income necessary to survive and support her children’s studies. She feels very content working in this field because she enjoys it and wants to continue with it. Furthermore, she milks her cows every day so that she can sell 20 liters a day to the dairy product companies. She will keep making an effort this way, above all to support her youngest daughter, who is currently in school. This is the second time that Lina requests a loan from MFP, and she has demonstrated punctuality in her repayments. She will use this loan to purchase a calf, thus increasing her number of cattle.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a calf

loans.name: Mut's Group

texts.en:
This small loan group is composed of three borrowers; the group leader, Mrs. Mut M. is 29 years old and sells different kinds of vegetables: cabbages, morning glories, onions, and Carrots, etc. She can earn an income of approximately US$ 2.50 per day, and she has been running her business since 2002. She is married with two children: both are still young and go to school. Her husband is a motorcycle taxi driver, who is earning an average of US$ 2.50 to help meet his family's needs.

M. is working hard every day to make sure both her children get higher education. Recently, M. sold all her vegetables and she plans to buy more vegetables for re-sale; that is why she is applying for a loan of US$ 300.

The other two borrowers are:

Mot R., a widow, is a local seamstress who is applying for a loan to repair her old house.

Taing L., 35, sells Khmer cake. She faces difficulties with her living conditions: her house is not so good and too small for them, thus she is asking for a loan to repair her old house.< P> The borrowers live in Prek Pras Sdac Commune in Battambang Province.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables for re-sale

loans.name: Deyanira Montero

texts.es:
Deyanira Montero J. es una madre soltera con 45 años de edad. Sólo tuvo un hijo que ya es mayor de edad y se atiende sólo. Ella vive en una pequeña casa donde también instaló su negocio, una pulpería (tiendita de abarrotes) para vender productos básicos a sus vecinos. 
La comunidad en la cual ella vive se llama El Sauce de Santa Teresita de Turrialba. Es una pequeña comunidad rural de unos dos mil habitantes. Sus pobladores se dedican a la producción de leche y siembra de café. Tiene un relieve irregular y mucho del terreno se mantiene como bosque tropical húmedo. La comunidad tiene paisajes muy pintorescos que combinan el bosque tropical con dos lindas lagunas, plantaciones de café y lecherías. El Sauce se localiza aproximadamente a hora y media en bus de Turrialba, el centro de comercio más cercano, sin embargo varias veces al año, el camino se vuelve intransitable por las lluvias que caen en la zona. Este es sin duda uno de los principales desafíos para la comunidad. Cuando no existían actividades muchas personas optaron por salir a buscar trabajos en Turrialba o en fincas bananeras ubicadas en el Atlántico de Costa Rica. Actualmente los precios del café y la leche han mejorado por lo tanto la población busca invertir con proyectos en la misma zona.
Doña Deyanira inició su negocio hace aproximadamente un año. Su objetivo es tener una actividad económica rentable que no la obligue emigrar a Turrialba a buscar trabajo como empleada doméstica. Aún no puede mantener abierto el negocio todo el tiempo que quisiera ya que no tiene suficiente capital como para invertirlo en comprar toda la mercadería necesaria. Ella comenta que al tener el negocio en su propia casa no tiene que pagar alquiler o construir un local lo cual le ayuda a que el negocio salga adelante.
Con el microcrédito que ha solicitado, ella desea comprar más mercadería que pueda vender para así hacer más grande el negocio y brindar un mejor servicio a sus vecinos. Específicamente comprará abarrotes básicos como arroz, frijoles, verduras, productos enlatados, refrescos, jabón, y todo lo que se refiere a la canasta básica del costarricense que vive en las zonas rurales. Deyanira comenta que el servicio que ella brinda es muy importante ya que no existe otra pulpería en la zona. Ella espera que el microcrédito le ayude a impulsar su negocio, colaborar con la comunidad y que las personas no tengan que viajar hasta Turrialba para comprar sus abarrotes.
Deyanira es cliente de la Asociación de Productores de El Sauce, una organización local socia de la microfinanciera EDESA. Gracias a su vinculación con esta organización, ella ha obtenido varios micropréstamos para su negocio los cuales ha pagado satisfactoriamente. Los montos han ido incrementando desde los US$ 200, US$ 550 y US$ 600. Actualmente ella necesita un préstamo por $1.000 para realizar la compra de la mercadería necesaria para ampliar su negocio.
texts.en:
Deyanira Montero J. is single mother who is 45 years old. She only had one son, and he is grown up and provides for himself. She lives in a small house where she also has her business, a small grocery store, where she sells basic products to her neighbors. The community in which she lives is called El Sauce de Santa Teresita de Turrialba. It is a small, rural town with two thousand inhabitants. They work primarily in milk production and coffee farming. It has a hilly topography and most of the area is maintained as tropical rainforest. The town has very picturesque landscapes that combine the tropical forest with pretty ponds, coffee plantations, and dairies. El Sauce is located approximately one-and-a-half hours by bus from Turrialba, the nearest center of commerce. However, several times per year the road becomes impassible due to the rains. This is, without a doubt, one of the greatest challenges for the community. When there weren’t many jobs, many people chose to leave to look for work in Turrialba or in banana plantations located on the Atlantic coast of Costa Rica. Lately the prices of coffee and milk have improved, so now people from the area are looking for ways to invest in projects there. Deyanira began her business approximately one year ago. Her goal is to have economically feasible work so that she won’t have to emigrate to Turrialba to work as domestic help. She still can’t keep her business open as much as she would like because she doesn’t have enough capital to invest in all of the necessary merchandise. She explains that having the business in her home means she doesn’t have to pay rent or construct a building, which helps her move ahead with her business. With the micro-loan she has requested, she hopes to buy more merchandise to sell and thereby grow the business and provide better service to her neighbors. Specifically, she will buy basic grocery goods, such as rice, beans, vegetables, canned goods, soft drinks, soap, and everything else that rural Costa Ricans typically need. Deyanira has commented that the service that she provides is very important because there is no other small grocery store in the area. She hopes the micro-loan will give momentum to her business and help her to collaborate with the community so that people won’t have to travel to Turrialbla to buy groceries. Deyanira is a client of the Producers Assocation of El Sauce, a local partner organization of the microfinance organization EDESA. Because of her ties to this organization, she has obtained several micro-loans for her business, which she has repaid satisfactorily. The amounts have increased from US$200.00, to US$550.00, to US$600.00. She currently needs a loan of $1,000.00 to buy the merchandise that is necessary to grow her business.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en: Blessing K. is a 40-year-old married woman with five children.  To support her family, she sells bags of charcoal to her customers (in wholesale and retail quantities).  She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $350 (50,000 NGN) in order to purchase more bags of charcoal for resale purposes.  She thanks Kiva and all its lenders for making this loan possible.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional bags of charcoal

loans.name: Felicitas Yanira

texts.es:
Yanira es socia del Banco Comunal Guadalupe.
Yanira es soltera, tiene 28 años y 1 hijo, Yanira trae ropa a pedido, sus ventas son al crédito, sus productos los adquiere en la ciudad de Lima. Además junto a su mama tienen un kiosco donde ambas venden comida.
Yanira necesita un préstamo de 1000 S., dinero que será invertido en la compra de uniformes escolares.
El sueño de Yanira es tener un negocio estable y sacar adelante a su hijo.
texts.en:
Yanira is a member of the Guadelupe Communal Bank. Yanira is 28 years old and single with one son. She carries clothing to order which she acquires in the city of Lima and sells on credit. In addition, together with her mother, they have a kiosk where they both sell meals. Yanira needs a loan of 1000 Sols which will be invested in the purchase of school uniforms. Her dream is to have a stable business and to bring up her son.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of school uniforms

loans.name: Sitalele

texts.en: Sitalele T. is 33 years old and married with 3 children. She has 3 years of experience in the fish business. She sells to people in the village and to the public 1 day per week. This is her 1st loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 60 Tala ($24 USD).  SPBD loans are Sitalele’s only access to capital because she is not able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets and fishing gears for her business.

loans.name: Miraflor

texts.en:
“I must work hard for my family” Miraflor M. said. She is 23 years old and lives at Casusan, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. At present, she is pregnant with her first baby. Excited, yet nervous - that’s what she feels right now. She already saves money for her delivery out of the income derived from her “sari-sari” (general) store.

Fortunately, she was granted a loan to start up her business from Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative in August 2008. She is a member in good standing and has paid the loan in full. Now, she applies for PHP 7,000 to buy additional goods for her sari-sari store. She hopes that, someday, she will be able to establish a good life with her family around her.

loans.use: To buy additional goods for "sari-sari" store

loans.name: Las Brisas Del Sur Group

texts.es:
el Grupo las Brisas del Sur, esta ubicado en coyolito, a escasos minutos del muelle de amapala, este grupo esta integrado por 3 personas las cuales son muy honrradas y trabajadoras. ademas tienen mucho tiempo de trabajar juntos. Las actividades de este grupo son las siguientes:
La sra. gladys F. de 48 años de edad, es soltera y reside en coyolito desde hace 35 años, ella de dedica a la venta de refrescos, jugos, tortillas con quesillo, tacos y tambien hace cenas de frijolitos con huevos, queso y tortillas. ella tiene 20 años de realizar esta actividad, de ella solo depende un niño y el esta en edad escolar. ella necesita el credito para poder comprar mas productos y asi tener una mejor ganancia.
Trinidad F. de 57 años de edad, es madre soltera, tiene 2 hijos, vive en coyolito, ella se ha dedicado al comercio desde hace mas de 15 años, ella vende refrescos y tiene una pequeña pulperia la cual no tiene mucho producto en ella por eso es que necesita el credito para poder surtirla.
Maura L. tiene 34 años de edad, ella vive en union libre con el Sr. Pablo Campos, el es dueño de un taxi el cual le genera ingresos para cubrir con algunos gastos del hogar, ellos tienen dos hijos los cuales estan en la escuela, ella se dedica a la venta de golosinas y necesita comprar mas productos para producir sus comidas las cuales se venden muy bien ya que este lugar de coyolito es un lugar turistico de honduras porque por aqui se tiene que pasar para ir a la isla de Amapala.
texts.en:
The "Brisas del Sur" group is in Coyolito, just a few minutes from the Amapala wharf. The group is made up of three honest and hard-working people who have worked together for a long time. Their business activities are: Gladys F. is 48 years old, single, and has lived in Coyolito for 35 years. She sells soft drinks, juice, tortillas with farmer's cheese, and tacos, and she also makes dinners with beans, eggs, cheese, and tortillas. She has been doing this for 20 years. She only has one child to support, and he is school-aged. She needs this loan to buy more supplies so she can have higher profits. Trinidad F. is 57 years old, a single mother of 2 children, and lives in Coyolito. She has been in business for more than 15 years. She sells soft drinks and has a small store, which does not have much merchandise. She needs this loan to stock it. Maura L. is 34 years old and lives in a common-law marriage with Pablo Campos. He is a taxi driver and earns enough money to cover some of the household costs. They have two children who are in school. Maura sells candy and needs to buy more supplies to prepare her meals, which sell very well since the area of Coyolito is a tourist attraction in Honduras. You have to pass through it to get to Amapala Island.

Translated from Spanish by Kelly Wester, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase soft drinks, meats, vegetables, canned juices, California brand juices, general merchandise

loans.name: Nicolas

texts.en:
Mr. Nicolas P. is from the city of Carapeguá and currently lives with his wife Aida in the district of Caazapá.

Mr. P. is known throughout the area as a hardworking and enterprising person. He dedicates himself to several commercial activities doing things such as selling milk and automobile lubricants door-to-door.  

Mr. P. is restarting his activities again as he recuperates from the loss of his 13-year-old daughter who died of cancer. Despite several problems in his life, Nicolas keeps fighting and working in order to move forward, and he has demonstrated that he is a man who keeps his promises.  

He will use the loan to buy automobile lubricants and other items to sell.

loans.use: Buy automobile lubricants and other items to sell

loans.name: María Gladis

texts.es: María Gladis C. D. V. D. 65 años D. edad resiD. en mejicanos junto a sus dos pequeños hijos. Posee una tienda D. productos perecederos y uso personal en su casa y solicita un préstamo con el fin D. poder comprar más productos para su negocio, así también desea comprar un estante en el cual pueda colocarlos D. una manera más ordenada y que sean visibles para sus clientes, ya que ella espera mejorar sus ganancias y darle un mejor estilo D. vida a sus hijos los cuales dependen únicamente D. ella.
texts.en:
María Gladis C. D. V. is 65 years old and lives in Mejicanos with her two small children. She has a small store in her home where she sales perishable and personal use items and is requesting a loan in order to purchase more products for her business. She also wishes to purchase a shelf on which she can arrange the products in a more organized way so they are visible to her clients. She hopes to increase her earnings and give a better quality of life to her children who depend only on her.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a shelf and additional products to sell

loans.name: Kalu

texts.en: For the past 15 years, Kalu M. has sold foodstuffs.  Forty-seven years old and married with four children, she hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth S. is a single parent with one child. She has been schooled through junior high school. Since 2007, Elizabeth has sold cooked yams and stew in Abura. Elizabeth uses her income to pay bills. Elizabeth will use the loan to expand her business by buying fresh yams and other ingredients for the food she prepares and sells. With the new profits from her expanded business, Elizabeth plans to re-invest.

loans.use: To buy yams and other ingredients

loans.name: Emmanuel's Group

texts.en:
M. Emmanuel is a businessman with a bar that he has owned for 8 years. He is a person who has worked hard for his family and business to the extent that he would like to see his bar grow much farther. At the moment, Emmanuel is able to make weekly profits worth 40,000/=, and his main challenge is that at times he gets threats of robbery. He is becoming conscious of buying his stock during the day and avoiding late nights.

Emmanuel needs a loan to be able to restock his bar with more beers, spirits and wines so that he will be able to make more profit. He is a married man with 4 children as he cares for 1 orphan plus paying their school fees and general upkeep.

loans.use: Restocking his bar with more drinks

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita G. is from the village of Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 57 years old. Nenita is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Nenita owns and operates a business selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Nenita has been in business for over 39 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Nenita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nenita is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase seafood products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Nenita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase seafood for resale

location.town: Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Khalid

texts.en:
Khalid R. has worked for many years in the difficult business of raising cattle. After purchasing his cattle, he provides them with all the right conditions for their growth: taking care of their food and protection and making sure they don’t get lost. Once they’re fully mature, he sells them in his area and also provides their milk for sale.

Currently, Khalid needs to purchase cattle to raise and for this reason he is turning to AqroInvest to obtain a loan of 2,000 USD. He thanks Kiva for the support that it presents to small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase one cow and two calves

loans.name: Liliam

texts.es:
Lilian es una socia activa y colaboradora, tiene 48 años D. edad, es madre D. tres hijos, dos mayores y uno menor D. edad, se dedica a la venta D. medicinas (tiene una botica)y también  tiene una pequeña fuente D. soda que funciona en su domicilio, ella trabaja junto a su esposo en ambos negocios. Es integrante del Banco Comunal “Las Gemas II” desD. hace dos años, en donD. se caracteriza por su puntualidad. Empezó con un préstamo D. 300 soles, que invirtió en gaseosas.  
Con este préstamo D. 1000 soles, comprará productos D. medicina. La meta D. Lilian es ampliar su fuente D. soda para poder vender también comidas típicas D. la región.
texts.en:
Lilian is an active and collaborative member. She is 48, and she has three children. Two are grown, and one is a minor. She sells medicine (she has a pharmacy), and she also has a small soda fountain in her home. She works with her husband in both businesses. She has been a member of the Las Gemas II Communal Bank for two years. In the bank she is known for her punctuality. She started with a loan for 300 PEN, which she used to buy soft drinks. With this loan for 1,000 PEN she will buy medicinal products. Liliana’s goal is to expand her soda fountain to be able to also sell food that is typical to the region.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy medicinal products

loans.name: Martin Ismael

texts.es: Martin Ismael S. tiene 32 años, el tiene 3 hijos a su cargo y todos asisten a clases con el duro esfuerzo que realiza. Su actividad económica es una pulpería, hace mas de 4 años que se dedica a este negocio a él siempre le ha gustado ganarse el pan de cada día de una manera muy humilde. El dio inicio a este negocio hace 2 años, empezó vendiendo recargas telefónicas, y más tarde decidió establecer golosinas. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo que será destinado para la compra granos básicos, jabón, detergentes, gaseosas y ciertos productos de limpieza. Su deseo es tener prosperidad en su vida y en su trabajo.

loans.use: capital de trabajo

loans.name: Sabita

texts.en:
Mrs. Sabita M. lives in the village of Dolchoki. Dolchoki is one of the least developed villages of Lalitpur. Dolchoki is located in a hilly region. Almost all the people in this region are engaged in agricultural farming.

Mrs. M. is engaged in goat farming. She sells goats to dealers. She started goat farming work more than five years ago. She is satisfied with her income.
